questions.text: A male child presented with easy bruisability leading to detailed investigations which revealed normal PT, prolonged APTT and normal bleeding time. Which of the following cannot be cause of his condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Von willebrand disease

 

The combination of normal prothrombin time (PT), prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), and normal bleeding time indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, which includes factors VIII, IX, and XI.

 

  • Factor 8 deficiency (Hemophilia A), Factor 9 deficiency (Hemophilia B), and Factor 11 deficiency (Hemophilia C) all cause a prolonged APTT with normal PT and bleeding time.

 

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) affects both platelet function and the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, leading to an increased bleeding time and often a prolonged APTT. However, the presence of a normal bleeding time in this patient rules out vWD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor 8 deficiency: This would present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option B. Factor 9 deficiency: This would also present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option C. Factor 11 deficiency: This would similarly present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isolated increased APTT can be caused by clotting factor deficiency of the intrinsic pathway like hemophilia A/B/C. von Willebrand disease is associated with increased bleeding time and increased APTT.

questions.text: A patient had a history of hepatic dysfunction, and the physical examination finding of the eye is shown below. Which of the following is the best way for confirmation of the diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver copper levels


The image shows a Kayser-Fleischer ring, which is a brownish or gray-green ring at the corneal margin, characteristic of Wilson's disease.

 

Wilson's disease is a disorder of copper metabolism leading to the accumulation of copper in various body tissues, including the liver, brain, and eyes. The Kayser-Fleischer ring, combined with hepatic dysfunction, strongly suggests Wilson’s disease.

 

The most reliable method for confirming the diagnosis of Wilson’s disease is measuring liver copper levels. Elevated hepatic copper content (greater than 250 µg/g dry weight) is diagnostic of Wilson’s disease, reflecting the abnormal accumulation of copper in liver tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum copper: Serum copper levels are usually low in Wilson’s disease because copper is not adequately bound to ceruloplasmin. However, this test is not specific or reliable enough to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option B. Urinary copper: Urinary copper excretion is typically elevated in Wilson's disease and can be used as a supportive test but is not the gold standard for confirmation. It is often used to monitor treatment response rather than for initial diagnosis.

 

Option D. Serum ceruloplasmin: Serum ceruloplasmin levels are often low in Wilson's disease, but this is not specific and can be influenced by other factors, making it unreliable as a sole diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:


Liver copper levels measured from a liver biopsy are the most definitive and confirmatory test for diagnosing Wilson’s disease, especially when characteristic signs like Kayser-Fleischer rings are present.

questions.text: A patient with chronic diarrhea develops dermatitis herpetiformis. The physician altered his diet which improved his symptoms. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. The immune system mistakenly targets gluten, along with the lining of the small intestine, leading to symptoms such as chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and weight loss. One of the hallmark dermatological manifestations of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition presents as a chronic, intensely itchy rash, typically on the elbows, knees, back, and buttocks, and is caused by the deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermoepidermal junction.

 

The improvement of symptoms following the alteration of the patient’s diet to exclude gluten is a classic indicator of celiac disease. Once gluten is removed from the diet, the intestinal inflammation subsides, and symptoms, including dermatitis herpetiformis, typically improve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whipple disease: Whipple disease is a rare bacterial infection that can cause malabsorption, leading to symptoms such as diarrhea and weight loss. However, it does not typically cause dermatitis herpetiformis, nor does dietary modification alone usually lead to symptom improvement.

 

Option C. Crohn disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. However, it does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and dietary changes like removing gluten do not usually lead to the dramatic improvement seen in celiac disease.

 

Option D. Lactose intolerance: Lactose intolerance results from the inability to digest lactose, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy products. It does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and the improvement in symptoms would be related to avoiding dairy, not gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be suspected in patients presenting with chronic diarrhea and dermatitis herpetiformis, particularly when symptoms improve following a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Target cell: can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the post splenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme.

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells:  are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells are seen in hairy cell leukemia, characterized by B lymphocytes with hair-like projections, and are identified using electron microscopy and specific markers like CD11c, CD25, CD103, and Annexin-A.

choices.text: Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status

questions.text: In breast cancer, FISH for gene amplification will be done based on which of the following IHC staining for Her-2/neu? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2+

 

In the context of breast cancer, the Her-2/neu status is typically assessed by Immunohistochemistry (IHC). The Her-2/neu protein overexpression is graded on a scale of 0 to 3+ based on the intensity and completeness of membrane staining. This grading is crucial in guiding further testing and treatment decisions.

 

  • IHC 0 or 1+: These scores indicate no or low levels of Her-2/neu expression, respectively. Tumors with these scores are considered Her-2 negative, and no further testing for gene amplification is typically needed.
  • IHC 2+: This score is considered equivocal. When a tumor shows a 2+ result on IHC, it suggests an intermediate level of Her-2/neu expression. Because this result is not definitively positive or negative, Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization (FISH) testing is recommended to assess for gene amplification of Her-2/neu. FISH is a more sensitive and specific test that directly detects the amplification of the Her-2/neu gene, providing definitive information about the tumor's status.
  • IHC 3+: A score of 3+ indicates a high level of Her-2/neu protein overexpression. Tumors with this score are considered Her-2 positive and typically do not require further FISH testing, as the overexpression is sufficient to warrant Herceptin (trastuzumab) therapy.

 

Herceptin is a targeted therapy that specifically inhibits the Her-2/neu receptor, which is overexpressed in some breast cancers, leading to more aggressive tumor behavior. Therefore, determining the correct Her-2/neu status through IHC and, if necessary, confirming with FISH is crucial in selecting the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1+: IHC 1+ is considered Her-2/neu negative, and FISH testing is generally not indicated in these cases.

 

Option C. 3+: IHC 3+ is strongly positive for Her-2/neu, making FISH testing unnecessary since the high expression level is sufficient to guide treatment decisions.

 

Option D. Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status: This option is incorrect because FISH testing for gene amplification is specifically indicated in cases with an equivocal IHC result (2+), not irrespective of Her-2/neu status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH for Her-2/neu gene amplification is performed when the IHC result is 2+, as this score is considered equivocal, requiring further testing to determine the appropriate therapeutic approach.

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysplasia

 

The hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and intact basement membrane are all suggestive of dysplasia.

 

Dysplasia is characterized by the loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and their architectural orientation.

 

The features of dysplasia include:

 

  • Pleomorphism
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
  • Increased mitotic figures

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma: In carcinoma, there is the invasion of the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Metaplasia: It refers to the replacement of one cell type with another type. It is almost always associated with tissue damage, repair, and regeneration. The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous.

 

Option D. Hyperplasia: It refers to the increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ. It can be physiologic or pathological. Enlargement of the female breast during pregnancy is physiologic hyperplasia. Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of pathological hyperplasia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal cellular features such as pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic figures, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. It involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane, distinguishing it from carcinoma, which involves invasion beyond the basement membrane.

questions.text: Which technique is used to identify auto antibodies? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect immunofluorescence

 

  • Indirect immunofluorescence is a technique commonly used for the detection of autoantibodies. It involves applying the patient's serum to a substrate that expresses the antigen(s) of interest. If autoantibodies are present, they bind to these antigens. Then another anti-human antibody is added to amplify the response generated. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Immunofluorescence: Used for tissue-bound antibodies where the patient's tissues are stained directly to detect deposits of immunoglobulins or complement.

 

Option B. ELISA: Mainly used for quantifying serum levels of specific antibodies against predefined antigens.

 

Option D. FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization): Used for identifying chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations rather than detecting antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect immunofluorescence allows for the detection of circulating autoantibodies in patient serum by using antigen-expressing substrates, making it a critical tool for diagnosing various autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ferroportin

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin.

 

Iron absorption is regulated by hepcidin, a small circulating peptide that is synthesized and released from the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels.

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferriportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, as hepcidin levels rise, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed. Thus, when the body is replete with iron, high hepcidin levels inhibit its absorption into the blood.

 

Conversely, with low body stores of iron, hepcidin synthesis falls and this in turn facilitates iron absorption. By inhibiting ferriportin, hepcidin not only reduces iron uptake from enterocytes but also suppresses iron release from macrophages, which are an important source of the iron that is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transferrin: Transferrin is a plasma protein that binds iron in the blood and transports it to various tissues, particularly the bone marrow for erythropoiesis. Hepcidin does not bind to transferrin; instead, it regulates iron export through ferroportin.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1): DMT1 is involved in the uptake of iron (in its ferrous form) from the lumen of the intestine into enterocytes. Hepcidin does not interact with DMT1; its regulatory effect occurs after iron has been absorbed into enterocytes, at the point of iron export into the bloodstream via ferroportin.

 

Option D. Ferritin: Ferritin is the intracellular protein that stores iron in a soluble and non-toxic form. Hepcidin does not bind to ferritin directly. However, by reducing the expression of ferroportin, hepcidin indirectly increases the storage of iron within cells in the form of ferritin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepcidin regulates iron homeostasis by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation, which prevents iron export from enterocytes into the plasma and from macrophages.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1231

choices.text: Transfusion related circulatory overload

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals Were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110 min. What is the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transfusion related circulatory overload

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).

 

Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 h of a blood transfusion - acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, increased blood pressure (BP), acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.

 

TACO may occur due to rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products.

 

Prevented is by slow transfusion at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic: Allergic reactions to blood transfusions usually present with urticaria (hives), pruritus (itching), and sometimes anaphylaxis, but do not typically cause the significant hypertension and tachycardia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI is characterized by acute onset of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, leading to respiratory distress and hypoxemia during or within 6 hours of transfusion. However, TRALI typically presents with hypotension or normal blood pressure, not the significant hypertension seen here.

 

Option D. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: This reaction typically presents with fever, chills, and rigors, but does not cause the hemodynamic instability (hypertension and tachycardia) seen in TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) is a potential complication of blood transfusion, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions like CKD. It presents with respiratory distress, hypertension, and tachycardia and can be prevented by careful monitoring and slow transfusion.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caspase – 1

 

Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1.

 

Pyroptosis is a type of controlled cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis that is mediated by IL-1. It takes part in the removal of microbially and necrotically affected cells.

 

Caspase-1 and the inflammasome complex are both activated.

 

  • IL-1 production causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Caspase - 3, C. Caspase - 9 and  D. Caspase – 8: These caspases are primarily involved in the apoptosis pathway, not in the activation of IL-1. Caspase-3 and caspase-9 are part of the apoptotic cascade that leads to programmed cell death without inflammation. Caspase-8 is involved in extrinsic apoptosis signaling and can overlap with inflammatory pathways but does not directly activate IL-1.

 

Educational objective:

 

Caspase-1 is critical for the activation of IL-1, directly linking it to the inflammatory response and distinguishing it from other caspases primarily involved in apoptotic pathways. This mechanism underscores the specific role of the inflammasome and pyroptosis in immune defense and inflammatory regulation.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome
Villous adenoma
Juvenile polyp

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

 

  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations. These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable. The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five. When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps. The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puetz Jegher syndrome: Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are neoplastic and present with a different histopathological pattern of finger-like or villous projections.

 

  • They are usually found in older adults and are not typically associated with painless rectal bleeding in children.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that can range from small polyps to large sessile lesions.

 

  • They do not exhibit the cystically dilated glands seen in juvenile polyps and are also more common in older adults.

 

Note - Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of rectal polyps in children under five, characterized by cystically dilated crypts and glands, and often present with painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. It is the most common sporadic renal tumor
  2. Associated with loss of long arm of chromosome 3
  3. Arises from distal convoluted tubule
  4. Cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4  

 

CLEAR CELL CARCINOMA (Most Common variant)

 

  • Mutation - VHL gene (Occasionally associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome). Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3.
  • Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions.
  • Radiographic findings - Hypervascular mass with homogeneous enhancement
  • Gross: Solid mass with a golden-yellow appearance
  • Histopathology - Clear cytoplasm due to washing of accumulated glycogen and lipid droplets. Prominent vasculature and sheets of polygonal cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3, not long.

 

Statement 3: Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, not distal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clear cell carcinoma of the kidney is the most common sporadic renal tumor and is characterized by cells with intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat, as well as an association with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1847-1849

questions.text: Which chromosome is involved in myotonic dystrophy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromosome 19

 

Myotonic dystrophy is an inherited genetic disorder that affects muscle function. It is caused by an abnormal expansion of nucleotide repeats in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19.

 

Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is a type of muscular dystrophy, a group of genetic disorders that cause progressive muscle loss and weakness. In DM, muscles are often unable to relax after contraction. Other manifestations may include cataracts, intellectual disability and heart conduction problems. In men, there may be early balding and an inability to father children. While myotonic dystrophy can occur at any age, onset is typically in the 20s and 30s.

 

There is no cure. Treatments may include braces or wheelchairs, pacemakers and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation. The medications mexiletine or carbamazepine can help relax muscles. Pain, if it occurs, may be treated with tricyclic antidepressants and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chromosome 20, Option C. Chromosome 21 and Option D. Chromosome 22: These chromosomes are not associated with the mutation causing myotonic dystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myotonic dystrophy is linked to a mutation in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19, leading to diverse symptoms including muscle dysfunction, cataracts, and cardiac issues.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin K dependent factors requiring gamma carboxylation? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 7, 9, 10

 

Vitamin K is essential for the post-translational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. This modification is gamma carboxylation, which allows these proteins to bind calcium ions and participate effectively in the coagulation cascade.

 

Vitamin K Dependent Factors:

 

  • Procoagulants: Factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X.
  • Anticoagulants: Protein C and Protein S.

 

These factors are synthesized in the liver and require gamma carboxylation of specific glutamic acid residues for their activity. Without this modification, they cannot bind calcium effectively, which is necessary for their role in coagulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K dependent factors are procoagulants (factors 2,7,9,10) and anticoagulants (protein C and S). They require gamma carboxylation for their activity.

choices.text: Joint pains with nodules on skin

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with history of back ache and polyarthralgia was investigated and found to have nucleolar pattern in IF. Which of the following is the best fit in her case? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly

 

Nucleolar pattern refers to the presence of a few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represents antibodies to RNA. This pattern is reported most often in patients with systemic sclerosis. Hence, Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly will be seen.

 

 

Systemic sclerosis is more common in middle-aged women. The clinical manifestations include:

 

  • Claw-like flexion deformity of hands
  • Raynauds phenomenon - manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, is seen in virtually all patients and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases
  • Esophageal fibrosis causing dysphagia and hypomotility
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Respiratory distress due to pulmonary fibrosis
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Biliary cirrhosis.

 

Other IF Patterns: -

 

Examples of ICAP-classified IIFA staining patterns:

 

 

 

ENA: Extractable nuclear antigens; RNP; ribonucleoproteins; SLE; systemic lupus erythematous; MCTD: mixed connective tissue disease; PM: polymyositis; dsDNA: double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid; CENP: centromere protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Genital and oral painful ulcers: These are more characteristic of Behet's disease, which is associated with HLA-B51 and presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and other systemic symptoms, not a nucleolar pattern on IF.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis and heart failure: These features are more consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which may show a different pattern on IF, such as a homogenous or peripheral (rim) pattern, rather than the nucleolar pattern associated with systemic sclerosis.

 

Option D. Joint pains with nodules on skin: This description is typical of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with rheumatoid nodules and not the nucleolar pattern seen in systemic sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleolar pattern in IF is most often associated with systemic sclerosis, a condition characterized by Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 405, 425

choices.text: Single positive blood culture for HACK group is a major criterion
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion
Complete dehiscence of prosthetic valve
Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke's criteria: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion

 

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single positive blood culture for HACK group is a major criterion: Incorrect terminology; it should refer to the HACEK group, and typically more than one positive blood culture is required unless other major criteria are also met.

 

Option C. Complete dehiscence of prosthetic valve: This would provide imaging evidence of endocardial involvement and thus falls under a major criterion if detected via appropriate imaging but is not accurately captured in this statement.

 

Option D. Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis: According to the Modified Duke’s Criteria, at least five minor criteria are needed to conclude infective endocarditis if no major criteria are met.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detection of C. Burnetti in a single blood culture is a major criterion for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis due to the organism's strong association with this disease, despite being difficult to culture.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to OPD with proptosis of left eye. On investigation, it was found to be a Desmin positive tumour. What can be the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario and tumor showing Desmin positive, points to a diagnosis of Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma presents as a soft gray infiltrative mass. The tumor cells mimic skeletal muscle at various stages of differentiation and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells. Rhabdomyoblasts with straplike cytoplasm and visible cross-striations may be present.

 

Sarcoma botryoides is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma that develops in the walls of hollow viscera such as the urinary bladder and vagina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is typically positive for CD99 and is more commonly found in bone or soft tissue, not usually associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Leukemia cells are positive for CD45 (leukocyte common antigen) and are not associated with Desmin positivity or presenting as a soft tissue mass with proptosis.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, typically presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and is associated with RB1 gene mutations. It is not associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, a common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma, is typically Desmin-positive and can present with proptosis, particularly when it arises in the orbit.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2435-2437

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaint of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and secondary sexual development. On examination, there was webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with the given condition? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45 XO

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder caused by complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in females. The key features that suggest Turner syndrome in this patient are:

 

  1. Delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea: Due to the presence of streak gonads (non-functional ovaries) in Turner syndrome, patients often experience delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods).
  2. Lack of secondary sexual development: The absence of functional ovaries leads to a lack of estrogen production, resulting in poor development of secondary sexual characteristics, such as breast development and pubic hair growth.
  3. Webbed neck: A short, wide neck with excess skin folds (webbing) is a common physical feature in Turner syndrome.
  4. Widely spaced nipples (shield chest): This is another characteristic physical finding in Turner syndrome, resulting from the altered body proportions.

 

 

The karyotype associated with classic Turner syndrome is 45,X (also written as 45,XO), indicating the presence of only one X chromosome instead of the normal two in females. This monosomy of the X chromosome is responsible for the clinical features observed in Turner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 47, XXX (Triple X syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in females but does not typically present with the features described in the question.

 

Option B. 46, XX: This is the normal female karyotype and does not explain the clinical presentation of the patient.

 

Option D. 47, XXY (Klinefelter syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in males and presents with different clinical features, such as tall stature, gynecomastia, and hypogonadism.

 

Additional information:

 

Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk of various complications, such as:

 

  1. Congenital heart defects (e.g., coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve)
  2. Metabolic syndrome (obesity, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia)
  3. Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis, celiac disease)
  4. Osteoporosis due to estrogen deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome, characterized by the 45,XO karyotype, should be suspected in a female patient presenting with delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, lack of secondary sexual development, and characteristic physical features such as webbed neck and widely spaced nipples.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a feature of delayed blood transfusion reaction?  (INICET MAY 2024)

  1. Increased unconjugated bilirubin
  2. Cola colored urine after 2 hours
  3. Increased LDH
  4. Failure of rise of hemoglobin after transfusion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 4

 

Delayed blood transfusion reactions typically occur more than 24 hours after the initiation of a blood transfusion. These reactions can result from various immune-mediated processes, often involving the destruction of transfused red blood cells. The features of delayed blood transfusion reactions include:

 

  • Increased unconjugated bilirubin: This occurs due to hemolysis, where the breakdown of red blood cells releases hemoglobin that is converted into unconjugated bilirubin.
  • Increased LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues, including red blood cells. When red blood cells are destroyed, LDH levels in the blood increase.
  • Failure of rise of hemoglobin after transfusion: Despite the transfusion, the hemoglobin level does not increase as expected because the transfused red blood cells are being destroyed.

 

Incorrect Statement 

 

Statement 2 Cola colored urine after 2 hours: Cola-colored urine shortly after transfusion is indicative of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, not a delayed reaction. Delayed hemolytic reactions typically present with cola-colored urine after several days, not within 2 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed blood transfusion reactions occur more than 24 hours after transfusion and are characterized by increased unconjugated bilirubin, increased LDH, and failure of hemoglobin levels to rise. Immediate cola-colored urine indicates an acute reaction, not a delayed one.

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and perform a direct Coombs test
Continue the blood transfusion and monitor urine output
Investigate for hemolysis after completing the transfusion

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a history of sickle cell anemia undergoes a blood transfusion. During the transfusion, he develops fever, chills, back pain, and dark urine. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and perform a direct Coombs test

 

Explanation:


The presentation of fever, chills, back pain, and dark urine during a blood transfusion is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR), often caused by ABO incompatibility or alloantibody-mediated hemolysis. The immediate step is to stop the transfusion to prevent further hemolysis and systemic complications. A direct Coombs test is essential to confirm hemolysis and identify the underlying cause. Other supportive measures, such as maintaining adequate hydration and monitoring renal function, should also be undertaken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Continuing the blood transfusion is inappropriate as it would exacerbate the hemolytic reaction and lead to further complications.

 

Option C: Administering antipyretics may mask symptoms but does not address the underlying hemolytic process and is unsafe to do without stopping the transfusion.

 

Option D: Investigating for hemolysis is crucial but should be done immediately after stopping the transfusion, not after completing it.

 

Educational Objective:


In suspected acute hemolytic transfusion reactions, characterized by fever, back pain, dark urine, and systemic symptoms, the immediate priority is to stop the transfusion and confirm hemolysis using a direct Coombs test. Prompt intervention is crucial to prevent renal damage and other complications.

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins.

 

CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (CJD)

 

  • Rare, degenerative, and fatal brain disorder.
  • Belongs to the group of transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs).
  • Results in the rapid deterioration of neurological function.

 

Causes

 

  • Abnormal prion proteins (misfolded) accumulate in the brain, leading to nerve cell damage.
  • Can be sporadic, genetic, or acquired through contaminated medical procedures

 

Symptoms

 

  • Rapidly progressive dementia.
  • Muscle stiffness, twitching, and weakness.
  • Behavioral changes, mood swings, and hallucinations.
  • Difficulty walking, speaking, and swallowing

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Based on clinical symptoms, medical history, and neurological examination.
  • Brain imaging and cerebrospinal fluid analysis to rule out other conditions.

 

Treatment

 

  • No cure or specific treatment available.
  • Supportive care to manage symptoms and maintain quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Primarily caused by chronic liver injury due to alcohol abuse, hepatitis, or other liver diseases, and is not related to abnormal protein folding.

 

Option C. Nephritic syndrome: Characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, hypertension, and proteinuria. The condition is generally caused by immune-mediated mechanisms, not by abnormal protein folding.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: While it is caused by a protein mutation, it is not related to the abnormal folding of proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a disorder caused by the abnormal folding of prion proteins, leading to severe and fatal brain degeneration.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is diagnostic for mixed connective tissue disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. U1-RNP antibody

 

Explanation: 

 

Mixed connective tissue disease is characterized by high titers of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP). This antibody is considered diagnostic for the condition, which presents with clinical features that overlap with those of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Patients typically present with synovitis of the fingers, Raynaud phenomenon, myositis, and renal involvement, which usually responds well to corticosteroids, at least in the short term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody - While anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in mixed connective tissue disease, they are not specific for this condition. ANAs are found in many autoimmune diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and Sjgren syndrome, so their presence alone cannot differentiate mixed connective tissue disease from other connective tissue disorders.

 

Option B. SCL-70 antibody - SCL-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase I) is associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), particularly the diffuse cutaneous form with increased risk of pulmonary fibrosis and peripheral vascular disease. It is not characteristic of mixed connective tissue disease.

 

Option D. Anti-CCP antibody - Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not typically found in mixed connective tissue disease and are used to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from other forms of inflammatory arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High titres of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP) are the serological hallmark and diagnostic marker for mixed connective tissue disease, a condition with overlapping features of several autoimmune disorders including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following nutrients can lead to delayed wound healing? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including DNA synthesis, cell division, and protein synthesis, all of which are vital for wound healing. Zinc is a cofactor for numerous enzymes, including matrix metalloproteinases, which are involved in the remodeling of extracellular matrix during wound healing. A deficiency in zinc impairs these processes, leading to delayed wound healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron is important for oxygen transport and cellular respiration, but its deficiency primarily leads to anemia and fatigue rather than directly causing delayed wound healing.

 

Option B. Magnesium: Magnesium is involved in many biochemical reactions, but its deficiency is more likely to cause muscle cramps, arrhythmias, and neuromuscular issues rather than significantly impacting wound healing.

 

Option D. Manganese: Manganese is a trace mineral important for bone formation and metabolism. While it is involved in enzyme function, its deficiency is less commonly linked to delayed wound healing compared to zinc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is required for functioning of matrix metalloproteases and so, required for proper wound healing. Any deficiency of zinc can lead to delayed wound healing.

questions.text: What is the type of inheritance shown in the Image: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AD

 

Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations. It is being transmitted from affected father to his daughter and son. Also, it is being transmitted from affected mother to her progeny. So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AR (Autosomal Recessive): Typically, AR inheritance shows disease in siblings, not across multiple generations, and both parents must be carriers.

 

Option C. XLD (X-linked Dominant): Affected fathers would transmit the disease to all daughters but not sons, and affected mothers can transmit to both sons and daughters.

 

Option D. XLR (X-linked Recessive): More common in males; females are typically carriers unless they have two affected X chromosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The presence of the disease in all three generations and transmission from both affected fathers and mothers to their progeny indicates autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance.

questions.text: An adult patient presents with short stature, blue sclerae, multiple fractures with minimal trauma, and hearing loss. This patient is likely to have a defect in which of the following? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type I Collagen

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation of short stature, blue sclerae, recurrent fractures, and hearing loss is characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), a genetic disorder of connective tissue primarily caused by mutations in genes encoding Type I collagen (e.g., COL1A1 and COL1A2). Type I collagen is a critical structural protein in bones, skin, and other connective tissues. The defect results in brittle bones, increased fracture risk, and the hallmark blue sclera due to the translucency of the sclera allowing visualization of the underlying choroid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fibrillin defects are associated with Marfan syndrome, which presents with tall stature, lens dislocation, and aortic aneurysms, not the features described here.

 

Option C: Elastase abnormalities are linked to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, causing emphysema and liver disease, not connective tissue fragility or fractures.

 

Option D: Laminin is involved in the structural integrity of tissues but is not related to the findings in osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Educational Objective:


Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder caused by defects in Type I collagen, leading to fragile bones, blue sclerae, and hearing loss. Early recognition is essential for managing fractures and improving the patients quality of life.

questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral small streak ovaries

 

The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen

 

  • Missing an entire X chromosome - this results in a 45X0 karyotype.
  • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes
  • Mosaics - they will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45/46X, (X)(q10).

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

Normal secondary sex characteristics do not develop during puberty. The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and pubic hair is scarce. In adults, short stature and amenorrhea are especially important in establishing the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: While Turner syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, such as coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, aortic dissection is less common in children and typically occurs in adults with significant aortic disease.

 

Option B. Subluxation of lens: Subluxation of the lens is a feature of Marfan syndrome, not Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Mitral valve prolapse: Mitral valve prolapse is more commonly associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Turner syndrome is more characteristically associated with left-sided heart defects like coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and streak ovaries, leading to primary ovarian insufficiency, infertility, and amenorrhea. The diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping, and the most likely finding in Turner syndrome patients is bilateral small streak ovaries.

choices.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Which of the following is true about red blood cells in Sickle cell anemia: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

 

In sickle cell anemia, red blood cells (RBCs) have abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) that causes the cells to sickle under low oxygen conditions. These sickled cells are more prone to mechanical damage as they pass through the microcirculation, leading to increased mechanical fragility. However, their osmotic fragility is lower compared to normal RBCs because the sickling and subsequent damage to the cell membrane makes them less prone to osmotic lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cells exhibit high mechanical fragility due to their abnormal shape and membrane characteristics under stress but display low osmotic fragility because they are less prone to rupture in varying osmotic conditions compared to normal red blood cells.

choices.text: Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV
Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV
Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below? (AIIMS NOV 2021)

 

(RS cell: Reed - Sternberg cell, HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus, CMV: Cytomegalovirus, EBV: Epstein-Barr virus)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV

 

The probable diagnosis, cell, and virus from the given clinical scenario and the histopathological image are Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) respectively.

 

Identification of Reed-Sternberg cells and their variants is essential for the diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are large cells (≥45 μm in diameter) with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus about the size of a small lymphocyte (5–7 μm in diameter).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma does not typically feature Reed-Sternberg cells. While EBV can be associated with some types of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the presence of RS cells is specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option B. Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV: Kaposi sarcoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and often presents with spindle cells and slit-like vascular spaces, not Reed-Sternberg cells. It is more commonly associated with HIV.

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV: Infectious mononucleosis is usually associated with EBV, not CMV, and while it can cause atypical lymphocytosis, it does not produce Reed-Sternberg cells, which are specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin's lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, and it is often associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), particularly in specific subtypes.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

 

The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

 

PBF Findings in acute lymphoblastic (ALL). The cell is large, with round to convoluted nuclei having high N/C ratio and no cytoplasmic granularity.

 

ALL is more common in childhood.

 

Clinical features of ALL include:

 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute monocytic leukemia and Option B. Acute myelomonocytic leukemia: These leukemias typically present with different morphologic features, including monoblasts and myeloblasts, which show different cytological characteristics such as cytoplasmic granularity and different nuclear morphology.

 

Option D. Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML): JMML is a rare childhood leukemia with a different clinical presentation, often including hepatosplenomegaly and elevated monocyte counts, and it does not present with the lymphoblast morphology seen in ALL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is characterized by the presence of lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and peripheral blood, along with clinical features of bone marrow failure and organ infiltration by malignant cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1113

choices.text: Trisodium citrate

questions.text: The vacutainer tube shown in the given image contains: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot Activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper indicating that it contains clot activator (silica). They don’t contain anticoagulants or additives.

 

The tube is inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: Na-EDTA is an anticoagulant used in vacutainer tubes with lavender or purple stoppers. These tubes are used for hematological examinations such as complete blood counts (CBC) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: Trisodium citrate is found in tubes with light blue stoppers and is used for coagulation studies such as PT (Prothrombin Time) and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time).

 

Option C. NAF (Sodium Fluoride): Sodium fluoride is an anticoagulant and preservative found in tubes with gray stoppers. It is used for glucose estimation as it inhibits glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Infective endocarditis on a rheumatic valve
Calcification and fibrosis of Mitral Valve
Hypertrophy of the left atrial wall

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and previous rheumatic fever presents with severe fatigue and palpitations. He dies suddenly, and autopsy findings reveal a mitral valve with a "fish mouth" appearance and superimposed vegetations. What is the most likely cause of death in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis on a rheumatic valve

 

Explanation:

 

The "fish mouth" or "buttonhole" appearance of the mitral valve is characteristic of chronic rheumatic heart disease, marked by calcification, fibrosis, and commissural fusion. The presence of superimposed vegetations on autopsy indicates infective endocarditis. Rheumatic valves, due to their deformed structure and altered blood flow dynamics, are predisposed to infection, leading to infective endocarditis. This condition is often fatal if left untreated, particularly in patients with underlying cardiac abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: While calcification and fibrosis are the primary changes in rheumatic heart disease, they do not explain the presence of vegetations in this case.

 

Option C: Rupture of chordae tendineae is seen in acute mitral regurgitation but is not related to the findings of vegetations and stenosis.

 

Option D: Hypertrophy of the left atrial wall occurs as a secondary change due to chronic pressure overload in mitral stenosis but is not the cause of sudden death in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic rheumatic heart disease, deformed valves are at high risk for developing infective endocarditis, particularly in the setting of atrial fibrillation or other contributing factors. Recognizing this complication is critical for timely intervention and management.

choices.text: Environmental enteropathy
Celiac disease
Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW)

 

Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.

 

Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

 

 

  • Prior to biopsy, noninvasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features: -
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma

 

Treatment – Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.

 

DAPSONE for dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages (see image below).

 

 

Option D. Chronic pancreatitis: Causes malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Not associated with the specific histopathological features seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

choices.text: Wilson's disease
Autoimmune hepatitis
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemochromatosis

 

The patient most likely has hemochromatosis. The liver microscopy image in the given scenario shows hepatocellular iron deposition is dark-brown in H&E stain (A) and blue in Prussian blue-stained section (B).

 

 

Hemochromatosis is defined by an abnormally high accumulation of body iron, the majority of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas. Iron can also build up in the heart, joints, and endocrine systems.

 

Hemochromatosis, also known as primary or hereditary hemochromatosis, is an inherited disorder caused by excessive iron absorption.

 

Secondary hemochromatosis, acquired hemochromatosis, or hemosiderosis refers to the accumulation of iron in tissues as a result of parenteral iron administration, usually in the form of transfusions, or other causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Primarily involves copper accumulation in the liver and other tissues, leading to liver disease and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

 

Option B. Autoimmune hepatitis: Characterized by inflammation of the liver due to autoimmune disorders, not associated with iron deposition.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency: Leads to liver and lung disease due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the liver, not iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron deposition in the liver and other organs, which can be confirmed by the distinct staining patterns seen in liver biopsy samples.

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver tissue
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis
White areas represent central hepatocytes

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which among the following is true about it? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

The above picture shows centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis. The cut liver section, in which major blood vessels are visible, is notable for a variegated, mottled, red appearance (nutmeg liver) seen in right heart failure. The dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver which resembles the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

 

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes:

 

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein
  • Bile duct

 

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

 

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area
  • Zone 2 is the Intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

 

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as nutmeg liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis: This is incorrect because the dark areas are where necrosis has occurred due to congestion, not viable tissue.

 

Option C. White areas represent central hepatocytes: The white areas represent periportal zones, which are generally healthier and not central hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Dark areas represent peri-portal hepatocytes: The dark areas actually represent the centrilobular regions where necrosis has occurred, not the periportal hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nutmeg liver is characterized by a mottled appearance, where dark areas represent necrosis due to chronic passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1665

choices.text: Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli
Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was put on mechanical ventilation. He passed away after a week. What is the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli

 

In a patient with severe COVID-19 who was on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs is, thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli.

 

COVID-19 is known to cause severe respiratory illness, and in severe cases, patients may require mechanical ventilation. One of the characteristic features of severe COVID-19 pneumonia is the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, including the accumulation of fibrin-rich hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls. This can result in the formation of a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, leading to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure.

 

While acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage, perivascular cuffing, and pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance may be seen in other respiratory diseases, they are not typically associated with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage: This may be seen in conditions like vasculitis or certain types of pneumonia but is not a hallmark of severe COVID-19.

 

Option C. Perivascular cuffing: This refers to lymphocytic infiltration around blood vessels and is more common in viral myocarditis and certain chronic lung diseases.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance: This is typically associated with chronic pulmonary hypertension and not an immediate feature of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with severe COVID-19, especially those who have been on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem finding in the lungs is a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe diffuse alveolar damage.

choices.text: Light green SF
Orange G
Eosin B

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Papanicolaou stain? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Eosin B

 

Eosin B is not a component of Papanicolaou stain.

 

Papanicolaou stain is the most popular stain used in the practice of histopathology. It is a polychrome stain containing multiple dyes to stain the various components of cells differentially. Papanicolaou stain includes both acidic and basic dyes:

 

The classic form of Pap stain involves five dyes in three solutions:

 

  1. A nuclear stain, hematoxylin, is used to stain cell nuclei.
  2. First OG-6 counterstain. The Orange G is used to stain keratin.
  3. Second EA (Eosin Azure) counterstain, comprising of three dyes
    • Eosin Y stains the superficial epithelial squamous cells, nucleoli, cilia, and red blood cells.
    • Light Green SF yellowish stains the cytoplasm of all other cells.
    • Bismarck brown Y – omitted in contemporary formulations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Light green SF: This dye is used in the Pap stain to color the cytoplasm of various cells green.

 

Option B. Orange G: This dye stains keratin and protein-rich components orange.

 

Option D. Hematoxylin: A nuclear stain used to color cell nuclei blue-purple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosin B is not a component of the Papanicolaou stain, which uses a combination of hematoxylin, Orange G, and Eosin Azure (including Eosin Y and Light Green SF) to differentially stain cellular components.

choices.text: Pernicious anemia with Vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with chronic fatigue, glossitis, and a tingling sensation in her hands and feet. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytic red blood cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pernicious anemia with Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Explanation:


The presentation of chronic fatigue, glossitis, and neuropathy (tingling sensations) alongside findings of macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear strongly suggests pernicious anemia, a form of Vitamin B12 deficiency. The atrophic gastritis observed on endoscopy supports an autoimmune etiology, where intrinsic factor production is impaired, leading to malabsorption of Vitamin B12. The neurological symptoms, which are unique to Vitamin B12 deficiency, further confirm this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Folate deficiency also causes macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils but does not typically lead to neurological symptoms or atrophic gastritis.

 

Option C: Iron deficiency anemia results in microcytic, hypochromic anemia and is not associated with macrocytosis or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option D: Sideroblastic anemia causes microcytic anemia and is linked to defective hemoglobin synthesis, not the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Pernicious anemia, an autoimmune condition impairing Vitamin B12 absorption, presents with macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and neurological symptoms. It is associated with atrophic gastritis and requires prompt recognition and treatment to prevent irreversible neurological damage.

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 60fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HbA2 levels

 

Question is testing applied knowledge. Mentzers index needs to be calculated 

 

A peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells and a Mentzer index of less than 13 indicates thalassemia. As a result, HbA2 levels (which are elevated in thalassemia) must be tested next.

 

The Mentzer index, also known as the MCV/RBC count, can be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). In both IDA and thalassemia, MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) are low. RBC count may be normal in thalassemia but decreased in IDA. A lower RBC count in IDA indicates a smaller denominator, resulting in a higher MCV/RBC ratio.

 

Mentzer index is

 

  • More than 13 in iron-deficiency anemia
  • Less than 13 in thalassemia

 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival.

 

Clinical features in thalassemia include anemia, jaundice, skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habits, growth impairment, and hepatosplenomegaly. Due to frequent blood transfusions, iron overload is also seen.

 

Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum ferritin levels: Relevant for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia but less specific for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Serum folate levels: Relevant for diagnosing macrocytic anemia due to folate deficiency, not typically useful for microcytic anemia.

 

Option D. Serum homocysteine levels: Elevated in cases of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, related to macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

For a patient presenting with microcytic hypochromic anemia and an RBC count suggesting thalassemia (Mentzer index < 13), the next best investigation is to measure HbA2 levels to confirm the diagnosis of beta-thalassemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about proto-oncogenes? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. KIT has decreased expression in GIST.
  2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
  3. ERBB2 over-expression is associated with breast carcinomas.
  4. PDGFR- has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 Only

 

ERBB2, also known as HER2, is a proto-oncogene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. Overexpression of HER2 is strongly associated with breast carcinomas, specifically HER2-positive breast cancers. HER2 is a significant marker in breast cancer, as its overexpression or amplification can lead to more aggressive tumor growth and is a target for specific therapies like trastuzumab.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. KIT has decreased expression in GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors): This statement is incorrect. KIT, also known as CD117, is commonly overexpressed in GISTs. The detection of KIT is often used diagnostically to confirm GIST.

 

2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma: This statement is incorrect. KRAS mutations are more commonly associated with non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), particularly adenocarcinoma of the lung, as well as colorectal and pancreatic cancers. 

 

4. PDGFR- has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers: This statement is incorrect. PDGFR- (Platelet-derived growth factor receptor beta) is generally overexpressed in gliomas and leukemias, rather than being suppressed in colorectal cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ERBB2 encodes for HER2, which is involved in Breast carcinoma. ERBB1 encodes for EGFR, which is involved in Adenocarcinoma of lung.
  • Genes involved in GIST are DOG1 > CD117 (cKIT) > CD34
  • KRAS mutations are cause of Lung, colorectal and pancreatic carcinoma. Gain of function mutation is seen in Adenocarcinoma of lung.
  • PDGFR- over-expression is seen in Glioma and Leukemia.

questions.text: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

Based on the patient's HbA2 and HbF levels, this patient likely has beta thalassemia major, a condition where the body produces less than normal amounts of hemoglobin beta chains. This results in a decrease in HbA, and an increase in HbF and HbA2.

 

Beta thalassemia will have high HbA2 levels (>3.5%) and slightly increased HbF

 

The peripheral blood smear of a patient with beta thalassemia major will show hypochromic microcytic red blood cells (Image 1), which are smaller and paler than normal. Howell-jolly bodies (image 2) will also be seen. These cells may also be more variable in size and shape, and may have a target cell appearance (Image 3) due to increased membrane-to-cytoplasm ratio.

 

Other possible findings on the blood smear may include anisocytosis (variation in cell size), poikilocytosis (variation in cell shape), and nucleated red blood cells (if the patient has severe anemia).

 

It's important to note that the blood smear alone is not sufficient to diagnose beta thalassemia major, and additional laboratory tests and genetic testing may be necessary for confirmation.

 

Image 2 shows HowellJolly bodies, which are small, round, dark purple inclusions within red blood cells (RBCs), representing residual nuclear DNA fragments. These inclusions are typically removed by a healthy spleen; their presence often indicates splenic dysfunction or absence.

 

Conditions Associated with HowellJolly Bodies

 

The presence of HowellJolly bodies is commonly associated with:

 

  • Post-splenectomy: Following surgical removal of the spleen
  • Functional asplenia or hyposplenism: Conditions like sickle cell disease can lead to spleen dysfunction
  • Megaloblastic anemia: Due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
  • Severe hemolytic anemia: Where rapid RBC destruction overwhelms the spleen's filtering capacity
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes: Bone marrow disorders affecting blood cell production

 

Educational Objective:

 

In beta thalassemia major, the peripheral blood smear typically shows hypochromic microcytic red blood cells and target cells, which are best represented by Image 1 and Image 3.

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enhancer deletion

 

Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene. On the contrary, deletion of an enhancer would likely reduce the expression of the gene, potentially reducing its oncogenic potential, rather than increasing it.

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promoter insertion: Can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene by increasing gene transcription.

 

Option C. Gene amplification: Leads to an increased number of gene copies, enhancing gene product levels, and contributing to oncogenesis.

 

Option D. Point mutation: A common mechanism for converting proto-oncogenes to oncogenes by altering the protein product to make it constitutively active.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transformation of proto-oncogene (i.e., normal cell proliferation gene) to oncogenes (i.e., cancer cell proliferation gene) may occur by three mechanisms:

 

  1. Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription. 
  2. Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls.  Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22.
  3. Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region,  ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 549-551

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with a lesion in the right eye and the histopathological image showed Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoblastoma

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of a lesion in the eye of a young child, along with the histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (small round blue tumor cells), strongly suggests the diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that primarily affects young children. It arises from immature retinal cells called retinoblasts. The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a characteristic histopathological feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes, consisting of a ring of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen, resembling the primitive neuroepithelium.

 

It is important to distinguish Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes from Homer Wright rosettes, which are pseudo-rosettes. Homer Wright rosettes are characterized by tumor cells arranged around a central neuropil (tangled cell processes) and are seen in various tumors of neuroectodermal origin, such as neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma.

 

 

While retinoblastoma can show both true rosettes (Flexner-Wintersteiner) and pseudo-rosettes (Homer Wright), the presence of true rosettes is more specific for retinoblastoma in the context of an ocular tumor in a young child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ocular melanoma: Ocular melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes in the eye. It is more common in adults and does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.
