Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin. While it can occur in the orbit, it does not show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve glioma is a benign tumor arising from glial cells of the optic nerve. It is more common in children with neurofibromatosis type 1 but does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (true rosettes) on histopathology of an ocular lesion in a young child is highly suggestive of retinoblastoma. It is important to distinguish these true rosettes from Homer Wright pseudo-rosettes, which can be seen in various other neuroectodermal tumors.

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity
  4. Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) presents with lowered serum iron levels, decreased transferrin saturation, elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and diminished ferritin levels.

 

1. Reduced Serum Iron

 

  • What it is: This is the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin in the blood.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, the body's iron stores are depleted due to chronic blood loss, poor dietary intake, or malabsorption, so there's less iron available to circulate.
    • Seen in IDA

 

2. Reduced Transferrin Saturation

 

  • What it is: This is the percentage of transferrin that is bound to iron.
  • Transferrin Saturation=Serum Iron/TIBC100
  • Why it decreases: Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, this ratio drops.
    • Seen in IDA

 

3. Increased Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)

 

  • What it is: This reflects the maximum amount of iron that transferrin can carry.
  • Why it increases: The liver increases transferrin production in an attempt to capture more iron from the gut when body iron is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

4. Reduced Ferritin

 

  • What it is: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron in cells and tissues.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, body iron stores are depleted, so ferritin levels drop.
  • Important point: Ferritin is also an acute-phase reactant and may be elevated in inflammation, but in pure iron deficiency, it is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

Summary Table

 

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

C. 1, 2, 3, 4 all of these changes are classical features of iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which gene is commonly associated with the development of a round blue cell tumor in a child who underwent surgery for ocular malignancy? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rb gene

 

Gene responsible for the tumor development is Rb gene

 

Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14 its mutation seen in retinoblastoma it is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.

 

Imp. Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Leukocoria (White pupillary reflex)
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P53 Gene: The P53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene involved in many cancers but not specifically in retinoblastoma.

 

Option C. P57 Gene: P57 is involved in the regulation of cell cycle and growth but is not associated with retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. RET: The RET gene is involved in multiple endocrine neoplasia and medullary thyroid cancer, not retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rb gene mutation is responsible for retinoblastoma, the most common intraocular malignancy in children.

questions.text: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AB

 

FFP from AB blood group can be given to this patient since the universal plasma donor is AB. AB plasma does not contain antibodies against antigens on RBCs of AB blood group.

 

Here, the question is about fresh frozen plasma transfusion and not about the packed red cells.

 

Had the question been about packed RBCs then in case of emergency packed cell blood transfusion with unknown blood group, O Rh-negative blood (universal donor) is transfused. It is preferred because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens. Hence, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B or anti-D antibodies in the recipient's blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker of carcinoid tumor? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-HIAA

 

Carcinoid tumors originate from enterochromaffin cells, which are rich in serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). Serotonin is metabolized to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in the urine. Elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine are indicative of a carcinoid tumor, particularly when the tumor is active and producing excessive serotonin. This makes 5-HIAA a reliable tumor marker for diagnosing and monitoring carcinoid tumors and the associated carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin is a tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, not carcinoid tumors. It is used to monitor patients with medullary thyroid cancer.

 

Option C. Catecholamine: Catecholamines are associated with adrenal medullary tumors, such as pheochromocytoma. They are not specific for carcinoid tumors.

 

Option D. Dopamine: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter and is not used as a tumor marker for carcinoid tumors. It is associated with different physiological and pathological processes, but not directly with carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinically, patients with carcinoid syndrome may present with a range of symptoms including hepatomegaly, bronchospasm that mimics asthma, episodes of vasoconstriction affecting blood vessels, increased intestinal motility manifesting as diarrhea, and distinctive flushing of the skin. The co-occurrence of symptoms like diarrhea, asthma-like respiratory issues, and hepatomegaly should immediately suggest the possibility of carcinoid syndrome.

 

An increase in the levels of 5-HIAA in blood and urine is a significant indicator (primary tumor marker) of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker is expressed on natural killer cell? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD 94

 

Natural killer (NK) cells are a type of lymphocyte that play a critical role in the innate immune response, particularly in targeting virally infected cells and tumor cells. They are characterized by the expression of specific surface markers, including CD 16, CD 56, and CD 94. CD 94 is particularly important as it forms part of the receptor complex that NK cells use to recognize and interact with target cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD 68: CD 68 is a marker for macrophages and monocytes

 

Option B. CD 3: CD 3 is a pan T-cell marker

 

Option C. CD 25: CD 25 is a marker for IL2

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 356-357

questions.text: Bilateral pedal edema is least likely to be associated with which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic venous insufficiency

 

Bilateral pedal edema is often due to systemic conditions that lead to fluid retention or increased pressure in the veins.

 

Chronic venous insufficiency, typically results from conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is more likely to cause unilateral (one-sided) pedal edema due to localized obstruction of venous return. While chronic venous insufficiency can sometimes cause bilateral edema, it is less common compared to the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic renal failure: Patients with chronic renal failure cannot excrete excess fluid properly, leading to fluid retention and generalized edema, including in both legs.

 

Option C. Congestive heart failure: Heart failure results in increased venous pressure and fluid retention, which typically causes dependent edema, including bilateral pedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic liver disease: Liver disease can lead to hypoalbuminemia and reduced oncotic pressure, causing generalized and bilateral pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency is least likely to be associated with bilateral pedal edema compared to chronic renal failure, congestive heart failure, and chronic liver disease.

 

Edema results from imbalances in:

 

  1. Hydrostatic pressure ( in heart failure)
  2. Oncotic pressure ( in liver/kidney disease)
  3. Lymphatic drainage
  4. Capillary permeability

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: Cowden syndrome is associated with mutation in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PTEN

 

Cowden syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by multiple tumor-like growths and an increased risk of certain cancers. It is associated with mutations in the PTEN gene, a tumor suppressor gene. This mutation leads to dysregulated cell growth and survival, contributing to the development of benign and malignant tumors, particularly in the breast, thyroid, and endometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. WT1: Associated with Wilms' tumor.

 

Option C. p53: Commonly mutated in various cancers but not specifically associated with Cowden syndrome.

 

Option D. Ras: Linked to a variety of cancers through different mechanisms but not directly to Cowden syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are side effects of nitrates, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Gastrointestinal disturbance

 

Explanation:

 

The adverse effects of nitrates are primarily related to their vasodilatory properties. These include fullness in head, throbbing headache, flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting. These symptoms occur due to postural hypotension and can be mitigated by lying down. Gastrointestinal disturbances are not characteristic side effects of nitrate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Orthostatic hypotension - Postural (orthostatic) hypotension is a well-documented side effect of nitrates. Standing still and alcohol consumption can accentuate this effect due to enhanced peripheral pooling of blood.
  • Option B. Tachycardia - With large doses of nitrates and significant drops in mean blood pressure, reflex sympathetic stimulation occurs, leading to tachycardia and increased cardiac contractility. This can paradoxically increase cardiac work and potentially precipitate angina.
  • Option D. Tachyphylaxis - Tolerance (tachyphylaxis) to the hemodynamic and anti-ischemic effects of nitrates develops in a dose and duration-dependent manner when they are continuously present in the body. This tolerance wanes rapidly (within hours) when the body is free of the drug.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nitrates produce side effects primarily related to vasodilation and can lead to tolerance with continuous use, but gastrointestinal disturbances are not characteristic of this drug class.

questions.text: Which form of heavy chain disease is most commonly associated with systemic lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma chain disease

 

Explanation:


Gamma chain disease is a rare form of heavy chain disease characterized by the production of abnormal gamma heavy chains (from immunoglobulin G, IgG). It often presents with systemic lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and, in some cases, symptoms of immunodeficiency. Unlike alpha chain disease, which primarily affects the intestinal mucosa, gamma chain disease is more systemic in nature, with lymphoproliferative involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Alpha chain disease is the most prevalent form of heavy chain disease but is primarily associated with gastrointestinal symptoms due to mucosal infiltration in the small intestine, not systemic lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C: Mu chain disease is exceedingly rare and often presents with features similar to chronic lymphocytic leukemia or lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.

 

Option D: Delta chain disease, involving IgD heavy chains, is extremely rare and does not typically present with systemic lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:


Gamma chain disease is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder associated with systemic manifestations such as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and potential immunodeficiency. It is distinct from other heavy chain diseases that may have more localized presentations.

questions.text: Which of the following proto-oncogenes is not implicated in carcinoma of thyroid? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) p53

 

p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene like other 3 options.

 

Proto-oncogenes are genes that, when mutated or overexpressed, have the potential to cause normal cells to become cancerous by promoting cell growth and division. On the other hand, tumor suppressor genes like p53 work to prevent uncontrolled cell growth. The p53 gene, often referred to as the "guardian of the genome," plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle, DNA repair, and apoptosis (programmed cell death). When p53 is mutated, it can no longer effectively suppress tumor growth, leading to the development of cancer. However, p53 is not categorized as a proto-oncogene and is not directly implicated in thyroid carcinoma as an oncogenic driver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 520

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass, which on histopathological examination had the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. The classical presentation includes leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and an intraocular mass. Histopathologically, the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a key diagnostic feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes characterized by a circular arrangement of tumor cells around an empty lumen, resembling a flower.

 

In this case:

 

  • Leukocoria is a typical clinical presentation of retinoblastoma.
  • The intraocular mass in a child further supports this diagnosis.
  • The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes confirms the diagnosis, as they are pathognomonic for retinoblastoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: While melanoma can occur in the eye, it is more common in adults and typically does not present with leukocoria or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Intraocular lymphoma is rare in children and typically presents differently, without the characteristic rosettes seen in retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This malignancy affects the ocular surface and is not typically associated with intraocular masses or leukocoria. It also lacks the histological pattern of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is identified by leukocoria, an intraocular mass in children, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology, which are true rosettes specific to this diagnosis.

questions.text: Pawn ball megakaryocytes are characteristic of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Explanation: 

 

Pawn ball megakaryocytes are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). These abnormal megakaryocytes have separated nuclear lobes instead of the normal single multi-lobated nucleus. The presence of these distinctive megakaryocytes is part of the dysmegakaryopoiesis that occurs in MDS, along with other features like ringed sideroblasts and pseudo-Pelger-Huet neutrophils. These morphological abnormalities reflect the underlying maturation defect at the level of myeloid stem cells that characterizes MDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. In ITP, megakaryocytes are typically normal or increased in number, but they do not show the characteristic pawn ball morphology. ITP is an immune-mediated disorder characterized by antibody destruction of platelets.

 

Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. TTP is characterized by microthrombi formation due to abnormally large von Willebrand factor multimers. The bone marrow findings in TTP do not typically include pawn ball megakaryocytes.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol toxicity - This is incorrect. Chloramphenicol toxicity can cause bone marrow suppression and aplasia, but it is not specifically associated with pawn ball megakaryocytes. It tends to cause a general hypocellularity rather than dysplastic changes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pawn ball megakaryocytes, with their distinctive separated nuclear lobes, are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes and reflect the dysplastic changes in megakaryopoiesis that are a hallmark of this group of disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B6

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

The sideroblastic anemia comprise a group of disorders of diverse etiology in which the nucleated erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, show characteristic ‘ringed sideroblasts.’

 

SIDEROCYTES are red cells containing granules of non-haem iron. These granules stain ositively with Prussian blue reaction as well as stain with Romanowsky dyes where they are referred to as Pappenheimer bodies.

 

SIDEROBLASTS are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue reaction. Depending upon the number, size and distribution of siderotic granules, sideroblasts may be normal or abnormal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: Important for DNA synthesis and prevention of megaloblastic anemia but not directly involved in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1: Known as thiamine, involved in carbohydrate metabolism, but does not play a role in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron supplementation would not help and could worsen sideroblastic anemia, as the issue lies in the utilization of iron, not in its deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia as it is a cofactor in the heme synthesis pathway and can correct the underlying metabolic defect in certain cases.

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Acute myeloid leukemia
Chronic myelogenous leukemia

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

 

The peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

The blood contains large numbers of small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells are usually disrupted in the process of making smears, producing so-called smudge cells. Lymphocytes are of same size and configuration with a uniform appearance called as "convent-girl" appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): The peripheral smear in ALL typically shows a high number of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. There would be an absence of smudge cells, which are characteristic of CLL.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML is characterized by the presence of myeloblasts in the peripheral blood smear. These cells are larger, have more cytoplasm, and may contain Auer rods. Again, smudge cells are not a feature of AML.

 

Option D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): The peripheral smear in CML shows a full spectrum of myeloid cells, from myeloblasts to mature neutrophils, often with an increase in basophils and eosinophils. Smudge cells are not a characteristic finding in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to OPD with swelling in the upper part of the tibia. X-ray revealed periosteal reaction in upper diaphysis of tibia. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario, immunohistochemistry showing positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 with histopath image showing small round blue cells, points to a diagnosis of Ewings sarcoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is an osteoid forming tumor. Patient usually complains of Night pain. But it neither shows small round blue cells on biopsy nor is positive for MIC-2

 

Option C. Metastatic neuroblastoma: Metastatic neuroblastoma also shows Homer wright pseudo rosettes, but it is positive for NSE, PHOX 28.

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma (Giant cell tumor): Osteoclastoma is a benign, locally aggressive bone tumor that is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells on biopsy. It typically affects the epiphysis of long bones and does not present with small round blue cells or positive staining for MIC-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing sarcoma is a small round blue cell tumor commonly occurring in the diaphysis of long bones in adolescents. It is characterized by positive immunohistochemical staining for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 (CD99).

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2390-2391

choices.text: Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1 mutation

questions.text: All leukemias come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumours except: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B-lymphoblastic leukemia/ lymphoma with hypodiploidy

 

It is not a provisional entity under WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

 

Leukemias that come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid are:

 

  1. Myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with PCM1-JAK2
  2. Refractory cytopenia of childhood
  3. AML with BCR-ABL1
  4. AML with mutated RUNX1 (Option C)
  5. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, BCR-ABL1like
  6. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with iAMP21
  7. Early T-cell precursor lymphoblastic leukemia
  8. Natural killer (NK) cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (Option A)
  9. Splenic B-cell lymphoma/leukemia, unclassifiable (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO 2016 classification introduced several provisional entities in hematolymphoid neoplasms, which are conditions that are newly recognized or still under study for their clinical significance.

 

B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with hypodiploidy is not a provisional entity under the WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

 

Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect.

 

Berry (Saccular) aneurysms occur when there is collagen deficiency in the internal elastic lamina and breakdown of the tunica media. An outpouching, consisting of only tunica intima and adventitia, protrudes through the defect in the internal elastic lamina and tunica media to produce the aneurismal sac

 

As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually ≤0.5 mm long.

 

The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm.

 

Saccular/ Berry aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm. About 90% of saccular aneurysms are found near major arterial branch points in the anterior circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN: While hypertension (HTN) is a risk factor that can exacerbate the progression of an aneurysm, it is not the primary cause of Berry aneurysm formation. The initial defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Option C. Endothelial layer defect: The endothelial layer is the innermost lining of blood vessels, but defects in this layer alone do not cause Berry aneurysms. The structural weakness in Berry aneurysms is primarily related to the internal elastic lamina and the underlying media.

 

Option D. Adventitia defect: The adventitia is the outermost layer of the blood vessel, but defects in the adventitia alone are not responsible for the formation of Berry aneurysms. The crucial defect is in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Berry aneurysms occur due to a defect in the arterial internal elastic lamina, leading to a weakened vessel wall and the potential for aneurysmal outpouching and rupture.

choices.text: CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

questions.text: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

 

The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl's eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia.

 

CMV is a -group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

 

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Small-cell lung cancer: This does not present with the characteristic owl's eye appearance seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. Cryptococcal pneumonia: Cryptococcosis is a fungal infection that can affect the lungs but typically presents with encapsulated yeast forms, not the cytomegalic cells characteristic of CMV.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: TB typically presents with granulomas and caseating necrosis rather than the cytomegalic changes seen in CMV pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of owl's eye intranuclear inclusions in pneumocytes on lung biopsy, especially in an immunocompromised patient, is strongly suggestive of CMV-associated organizing pneumonia.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 639-640
